ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned about the history of Francophone North America, developed research skills and archival skills for paper writing.
Basic background of Canadian history
Great class! Lots about the history of Canada that I had no idea about.
French-english relations in North America, multiculturalism, national identity, politics of language and culture,
Learned about Canadian history and the history of French North America  both of which I knew too little about

I am now able to intelligently talk about the broad arc of Canadian history, which was something I was wholly ignorant of prior to taking this class. I also gained research skills, since this course culminates with a 20 page paper.
writing and discussion skills, history of canada

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: class was really interesting and engaging, great Professor 

Weaknesses: lots of reading, no accountability
A lot of context and topics relating to history: literature, music, etc.
Very well-taught
This is a wonderful class with great readings. My one critique is that I think there could have been more class discussion.

Strengths: professor, don't need to do the reading, excellent learning environment
Weaknesses: surprise assignments, not always clear expectations
A strength of this class is its unique subject matter. One small improvement would be a lessening of the reading load, as it was heavy enough to make completing every assignment difficult.
strength it was fun and not a ton of work, weakness you don't get a lot of feedback on your grade/how you're doing in the course

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you're Canadian, Louisianian, French, or in any way connected to French culture, take the course. If you aren't but are interested in French America, take the course. The course covers so much more than just Canadian and Quebecois history. Every bit of this class is absolutely amazing.
Yes - it's very chill and a fun low-workload class.
Yes, but be aware the entire course is basically just your final paper.
Yes, it was a wonderful history seminar on a topic I previously knew little about.
Yes
Gitlin is a treasure. This class is so much fun.
I would recommend this course to another student. Professor Gitlin makes every class super engaging and enjoyable.

Absolutely!! Professor G is incredibly kind and one of the most engaging professors I have ever had at Yale. His enthusiasm for the content is infectious and no matter your background, you will learn so much from this course (and find a lot of joy in the process)!
Take it  great history credit

I would definitely recommend the class, as it is a relatively easy history credit that focuses on a subject not often discussed in other classes. While the course is definitely more of a lecture than a seminar, it's a very enjoyable lecture.
yes, Gitlin cares about his students and makes it a really engaging community for the class. there are field trips and fun class formats every week
